content.description:
Shaft Crack shares a start with

Complete Crack

. Climb the arete to your right to an easy roof. A couple of face moves into the corner will get you to the top.

Start with an easy layback, and continue with comfortable jamming until it becomes awkward (crux). There are two options: either squeeze your way up facing out (easier), or move up the slab directly on slopey holds (harder). Finish at a 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: This ascends the obvious, rightmost corner crack.

content.description:
Start from just right of

Eenie

on the small platform above the main trail.
content.protection:
5 bolts. It shares anchors with

Eenie

.

content.description: Climb gently, the softest rock at the Butte exists on this route. Climb the huecos through bulges. This is a really good route.
content.location: In the middle of the wall, look for huecos.

content.description: The original Gold Butte guidebook shows this as being a mixed route. Bring a couple fingers and hand size cams to supplement the bolts. I will update this after climbing it!
content.protection: Bolts and #0.75 and #2 cams or equivalent passive gear to anchors.

content.description: Start on the arete, and traverse left to reach the anchors.
This route doesn't get climbed as much as it should for the area. It's a steep, juggy 5.8 with great moves for a new lead climber. There is a ledge to belay from above the main trail.
content.protection:
4 bolts to anchors.

You can toprope this route, but I would recommend leading it only, as a fall on TR will send you into space above the main trail and possibly pull your belayer off at the same time.

content.description:
This shares a start with

Shaft Crack

, traversing left over the pocket into an obvious corner system. Use the crack for a variety of fun moves, and finish just above the giant flake.
content.location: One of the more popular climbs on this face, it's hard to miss the small "cave" right below this route. This is about ten feet up from the fork in the path (approaching from either direction).

content.description: This is a mixed gear and bolt route. The guidebook recommends #2, #3, and #4 cams for supplementary protection.

This is the first route on the crag when approaching from the north. This is a steep and juggy boulder problem protected by a couple of bolts. Toproping is possible by approaching via the obvious ledge, but you might want to think twice before putting your rope (and the rock) through that much torture.
content.protection: Two bolts to a ledge with anchors.
